{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2979860,"name":"","username":"Candace","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/4da419/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-12-04T16:12:45.803Z","cooked":"

I have seen all the buzz about Running First WPILib on the Romi Robot and was wondering if it was possible to do a similar thing with an Elegoo Smart Car. A number of the teams in my area received a grant last year to get an Elegoo Smart Car for each of our students. It would be really amazing if we could add a Raspberry Pi to them and then run WPILib and code in Java.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":3,"updated_at":"2021-12-04T16:12:45.803Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":97,"reads":72,"readers_count":71,"score":499.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":397826,"topic_slug":"running-wpilib-with-a-raspberry-pi-on-an-elegoo-smart-car","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49981,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/running-wpilib-with-a-raspberry-pi-on-an-elegoo-smart-car/397826/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":2979880,"name":null,"username":"veg","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/v/3be4f8/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-12-04T18:15:33.166Z","cooked":"

In theory, yes this is possible.

The WPILib source code for the Arduino controller on the Romi is not terribly complicated to understand. It talks to the Raspberry Pi over the I2C bus to implement the low-level motor control, sensor I/O, and other functionality. You would need to modify the Arduino project to map the I/O onto the available features of the Elegoo platform.

You won’t have some of the sensors that are integrated on the Romi - specifically the accelerometer/gyro and the wheel encoders, so you’ll probably need to stub out some functionality, or augment the Elegoo with additional hardware. But that shouldn’t prevent you from driving a platform around under simple WPILib control.

You’ll also need to work out the interfacing between your Raspberry Pi and your Romi, as these operate at different voltage levels. The Romi is nice in this area because it is basically a Raspberry Pi hat with all the required level shifters. Pololu has a couple of other Arduino-compatible controllers that have the same kind of interface, so you could replace the Uno on the Elegoo with one of those options.

At the end of the day, it’s not a simple project. But it might be worth doing anyway, if you have enough students who would benefit from using it.
